qas.question: How long have Masonic Lodges been in Iraq?

answers.text: the United Grand Lodge of England

plausible_answers.text: the United Grand Lodge of England

qas.question: Who opened the only Lodge in Iraq?

context: Masonic lodges existed in Iraq <a0_0><b10_0>as early as <a5_0>1917<b10_0/><a5_0/><a0_0/>, when the first lodge under <a6_0><b14_0>the United Grand Lodge of England<b14_0/><a6_0/> (UGLE) was opened. <a1_0><b11_0>Nine<b11_0/><a1_0/> lodges under UGLE existed by the 1950s, and a Scottish lodge was formed in <a4_0><a7_0><b13_0>1923<b13_0/><a7_0/><a4_0/>. However, the position changed following the revolution, and all lodges were forced to close in <a3_0><a8_0>1965<a8_0/><a3_0/>. This position was later reinforced under <a9_0>Saddam Hussein<a9_0/>; <a2_0><b12_0>the death penalty<b12_0/><a2_0/> was "prescribed" for those who "promote or acclaim Zionist principles, including freemasonry, or who associate [themselves] with Zionist organisations."
